title-group.article-title: Agrocinopine C, a Ti-plasmid-coded enzyme-product, is a 2-O, 6-O linked phosphodiester of D-Glucose and sucrose

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Agrobacterium radiobacter (Beijerinck and van Delden) Conn
Rhizobium rhizogenes (Riker et al.) Young et al.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Agrocinopine C, a Ti-plasmid-coded enzyme-product, is a 2-O, 6-O linked phosphodiester of D-Glucose and sucrose ☆
Robert E. Asenstorfer, Maarten H. Ryder * , Graham P. Jones
School of Agriculture , Food and Wine, University of Adelaide, Waite Research Institute , PMB 1, Glen Osmond , South Australia , 5064, Australia
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Ti plasmid
Plant biochemistry
Sugar transport
Crown gall
Agrocinopine
Sucrose phospho-diester
Permease induction
Acyclic aldehyde-anomers
A B S T R A C T

Agrocinopine C is a small molecule found in crown gall tumours induced by pathogenic
Agrobacterium radiobacter
carrying the tumour-inducing plasmid pTi Bo542. This phosphodiester opine was isolated (at 0.02 g / 100 g fresh wt.) from sunflower (
Helianthus annuus
L.) galls. It is structurally related to agrocinopine A and is a glucose-2- phosphodiester linked to the C6-hydroxy-methyl group of the glucose moiety of sucrose. Sugar-2-phosphates are uncommon in plant tissues, whether transformed by
Agrobacterium
or not. 1 H and 31 P NMR signal multiplicity indicates five-fold anomeric complexity of agrocinopine C in solution, implying that the permeases taking up these sucrose-phosphodiesters could recognise any one of the five anomers. Data suggests that the open chain aldehyde forms of the 2-phosphorylated opines agrocinopine C and agrocinopine A and the corresponding phosphorylated glucose-2-phosphoramidate component of the antibiotic agrocin 84 play a central role in agrocin’ s selective toxicity to certain strains of
Agrobacterium
after uptake via Ti plasmid-encoded permeases.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: ☆ This paper is dedicated to the memory of Anna E. Savage (dec’ d 1997) and Max E. Tate (dec’ d 2016) and is based on their and Maarten Ryder’ s initial studies. * Corresponding author.
E-mail address: maarten.ryder@adelaide.edu.au (M.H. Ryder).

The purpose of the current paper is to provide evidence for the structure of agrocinopine C present in plant tumours incited by pathogenic
A. radiobacter
which carry the Ti-plasmid pTiBo542, and to emphasise the hitherto unrecognised complexity of the anomeric equilibria for solutions of agrocinopines A and C in addition to the corresponding anomeric complexity in solutions of the structurally-related, naturally occurring fraudulent adenine-dinucleotide bacteriocin, agrocin 84.

sec.title: 2.1. High resolution mass spectrometry
sec.p: The agrocinopine C negative ion (M-H) gave an observed mass 583.1275 m /z ( Fig. 1 ), the calculated mass for the M-H formula: C 18 H 32 O 19 P is 583.1281. The ionisation pattern, m/z (relative intensity; ion), gave 583.1275 (b.p.; M-H + ) - , 421.0740 (0.37; M-H + -glucose) - , 353.2107 (0.09; M-H + -229.9168) - , 283.2625 (0.13; M-H + -229.8650) - , 255.2318 (0.25; M-H + -327.8957) - , 112.9852 (0.54; H 2 PO 5 ) - , 96.9602 (0.13; H 2 PO 4 ) - . The ion at m/z 421.0740 indicated a loss of glucose, peaks at 353.21, 283.26 and 255.23 m /z suggested fragmentation of the remaining sucrose-phosphate moiety, while the peak 96.6 m /z was consistent with dihydrogen phosphate.

sec.title: 2.2. Infrared spectrum
sec.p: IR (diffuse reflectance; Fig. 2 ): ν = 3402 (OH, stretch), 2929 ( CH 2 asymmetric vibration), 2863 ( CH 2 symmetric vibration), 1623 (OH deformation, 1412 ( CH bending), 1353 (P––O), 1101 (OH–P––O), 1035 (C–O, C–C vibration), 847 ( CH deformation), 812 ( CH deformation), 683, 618 ( CH 2 ), 592 cm 1 .

sec.title: 2.3. pH mobility profile
sec.p:
Fig. 3 shows the characteristically linear pH mobility profiles for the phosphodiesters agrocinopines C and D and a two-step dissociation profile for the ribose 5-phosphate monoester control. The biological activity of agrocinopine C following electrophoretic separation and further purification steps was detected in the plate bioassay (Fig. 4) developed by
.

sec.title: 2.4. Agrocinopine C component moiety ratios
2.5. Alkaline degradation
sec.p: Ammonolysis products (1.5 M NH 4 OH/110 ◦ C/40min, sealed tube) separated by electrophoresis at pH 1.7 (formic/acetic buffer) yielded neutral sugars ( RmOG 0.0), unresolved D-glucose mono-phosphates ( RmOG 0.61) and inorganic phosphate ( RmOG 0.53).

Ammonium borate (0.2 M) electrophoresis (pH 9.2) of the ammonolysis neutral sugar (pH 1.7) fraction showed the presence of glucose ( RmOG 0.91) and sucrose ( RmOG 0.09). Electrophoretic separation of the glucose phosphates ex ammonolysis indicated the presence of unresolved cyclic glucose 1,2- and 2,3-phosphates ( RmOG 0.81), glucose 1- phosphate ( RmOG 0.97), glucose 2-phosphate ( RmOG 1.11) and glucose 3-phosphate ( RmOG 1.27). Alkaline phosphatase (E.C. 3.1.3.1) treatment (32 ◦ C/2 h) converted all glucose phosphates to D-glucose ( RmOG 0.83) and inorganic phosphate. Treatment of the glucose (32 ◦ C/1 h) with glucose oxidase (E.C. 1.1.3.4) smoothly converted it quantitatively to Dgluconate ( RmOG 1.07).

sec.title: 2.6. Borohydride reduction of agrocinopine C
sec.p:
Addition of a slight excess of sodium borohydride (NaBH 4 , 0.6 mol per mole of aqueous agrocinopine C) produced a compound ( RmOG 0.55, pH 1.7) that was no longer positive to the p -anisidine reagent for reducing sugars (
). Ammonolysis (1.5 M NH 4 OH) followed by alkaline phosphatase (EC 3.1.3.1) treatment yielded a non-reducing polyol ( RmOG 0.94; 0.2 M ammonium borate buffer pH 9.2), which was indistinguishable from D-glucitol ( RmOG 0.94). Electrophoresis of this polyol in a lanthanum trinitrate buffer (0.2 M in 0.75 M formic acid/1 M acetic acid) produced a cationic (lanthanum-complex) polyol spot ( RmOG 0.71) indistinguishable from a reference sample of D-glucitol ( RmOG 0.71).

sec.title: 2.7. Acid degradation
2.8. NMR data for agrocinopine C
sec.p:
At the time of the original isolation (by A.E.S, 1983) the complexity of the isomeric proton NMR data due to the available instrumentation was not interpreted, nevertheless the greater resolution of the proton decoupled 13 C NMR data provided good support for the proposed structure for agrocinopine C based around the observed degradation data (
). Recent 13 C NMR data obtained using the HSQC protocol agreed well with the data collected in 1983 and has permitted detailed and improved assignments ( Table 1 ).

Proton NMR (estimated purity 76.2%) exhibited ten methylene signals ( 4.070 –3.324 ppm), four methine ( 3.519 –3.704 ppm) and major signals for two anomeric protons 5.269 ppm and 5.271 ppm, glucose-2- phosphate and the glucose unit of sucrose respectively ( Table 1 , Figs. S1–S 3 ). The glucose-2-phosphate anomeric proton had four signals indicating the presence of the α- pyranosyl, β- pyranosyl, α- furanosyl and β- furanosyl anomers ( Table 2 ). Two signals observed in the HSQC ( Fig. S4 ) for glucose-2-phosphate g5 proton, 3.706 ppm and 3.714 ppm, confirm the presence of the pyranosyl and furanosyl anomers. Similarly, two pairs of signals observed for the g2 and g3 protons were associated with the pyranosyl and furanosyl anomers.

Coupling constants of the methylene glucose protons g2 (pyrano, 4.066 ppm/furano, 4.070 ppm) and g3 (3.928 ppm) were 8.9 Hz, 8.5 Hz, respectively. Both shifts and coupling constants were clearly influenced by the presence of phosphate when compared with the 1 H NMR of glucose (MestReNova, 2014). The non-phosphorylated glucose g2 proton had a shift of 3.233 ppm (double-doublet) while the g3 had shift of 3.728 which was not resolved from the g6 protons. The glucose unit of sucrose methylene proton sg5 (3.441 ppm) had three coupling constants (j =0.9, 3.9, 10.0 Hz) consistent with coupling with the sg6 protons as well as long range coupling with the phosphate. Coupling constants of the methine protons sg6 (3.995 ppm) (dd; j =3.3; 5.5 Hz) also indicated coupling with the phosphate. Expected doublets for the anomeric protons g1 and sg1 (5.269 ppm and 5.271 ppm) were not resolved.

Protons at 4.070 ppm (j =8.9 Hz) and 3.995 ppm (j = 3.3, 5.0 Hz) were coupled with phosphate. The 31 P NMR (estimated purity 85.4%) indicates the presence of both pyranosyl (3.241 ppm) and furanosyl anomers (2.80 ppm) with no splitting of the individual anomers ( Fig. 5 ). The aldehyde/gemdiol, which cannot be differentiated, can be observed at 4.029 ppm. 1 H – 31 P gHMBC confirmed that only these three phosphate signals were associated with agrocinopine C ( Fig. S6 ). These three signals collapsed into a single peak when the glucose-2- phosphate was reduced by sodium borohydride to give glucitol-2- phosphate (1.55 ppm) which only has a single anomer ( Fig. 5 ).
3. Discussion

The high-resolution mass spectrum for the agrocinopine C sample provided an elemental M-H anion composition (C 18 H 32 O 19 P) which corresponds to that for a phospho-diester linking sucrose to a hexose instead of the pentose (L-arabinose) observed for agrocinopine A (
). An erroneous preliminary structure for agrocinopine C based on an in vitro synthesis was reported by
and subsequently in a review by
, and this must be corrected. In agrocinopine C, D-glucose-2-phosphate is linked to the 6-hydroxymethyl carbon of the glucopyranosyl moiety of sucrose ( Fig. 6 ) and consequently it is the fructosyl moiety which is lost by brief acid hydrolysis of the labile sucrose C1α- linkage of glucose to C2α- fructose to yield agrocinopine D. In contrast, agrocinopine A has L-arabinose-2-phosphate linked to the C4-hydroxyl of the fructo-furanosyl moiety of sucrose and it is glucose that is lost by brief acid hydrolysis (yielding agrocinopine B).
a 22.5 MHz (JEOL FX90Q).
b HSQC.
c HMBC (600 MHz Varian).
d NOESY coupling between Hsg2 and Hsf1.
e HMBC 31 P, phosphate at 2.80 ppm is coupled to protons at 4.070 ppm and 3.996 ppm.
f see
Table 2 for anomers.

It is remarkable that two quite different Ti plasmids (the Bo542 agropine and the T37 nopaline plasmid) contain biosynthetic genes on their T-DNAs for two related phospho-diesters of sucrose. The close structural relationship of the glucose-2-phosphoramidate motif of agrocin 84 (Fig. S7) to the glucose-2-phosphodiester of agrocinopine C is evident.

Firstly, examine whether the 31 P signal multiplicity is increased by slowing down the rate of anomerisation, by lowering the temperature as, for example, in the case of L-arabinose-2-phosphate (Fig. S8).
Secondly, observe whether borohydride reduction of the acyclic carbonyl collapses the phosphorylated reducing sugar 31 P multiplet to a polyol-phosphate singlet ( Fig. 5 , Fig. S8).
Thirdly, two-dimensional NMR, 1 H– 31 P HMBC provides information regarding the correlation between closely linked protons and phosphate atoms ( Fig. S6 ).

Sodium borohydride reduction of glucose-2-phosphate to a glucitol–phosphoryl moiety in agrocinopine C removed its effect in the agrocin 84/
A. radiobacter
strain K478 bioassay. Similarly, sodium borohydride reduction of agrocinopine A converted the arabinose 2- phosphoryl moiety to the corresponding L-arabinitol 2-phosphoryl moiety and this molecule no longer enhanced the diameter of the inhibition zone in an agrocin 84 bioassay overlaid with the nopaline/agrocinopine A type pathogenic
A. radiobacter
strain A208 (
). The simplest explanation for this loss of biological activity of the agrocinopines after reduction of the aldehyde to the polyol, is that the carbonyl of the acyclic aldehyde group plays a pivotal role in binding the reducing sugar moieties to the respective periplasmic binding proteins responsible for their uptake by the pathogen. Transient condensation of the carbonyl group of the acyclic aldehyde anomers of reducing sugar species, with an α- amino group of a binding protein or the free amino group of a membrane lipid as for example phosphatidyl ethanolamine or phosphatidyl serine to form a lipophilic-complex with a weak (-C-OH. NH-) bond, enables transport into the cell. Imine formation, such as this, is favoured at pH 5 which is close to physiological pH. The toxic agrocin 84 enters the cell using the same mechanism (Fig. S7). Once inside the cell, with subsequent hydration in a different pH environment, the transiently bound phosphorylated reducing sugar is released, thereby achieving transport across a very hydrophobic lipid bilayer.

Two non-pathogenic
R. rhizogenes
strains, K84 and its derivative K1026, have provided world-wide protection against the plant cancer known as crown gall caused by pathogenic strains of
Agrobacterium
on stone fruits and roses for more than four decades. Agrocin 84 production by these strains, and the uptake of this “pro-toxin” by crown gall-inciting
Agrobacterium
and
Rhizobium
is critically important to the success of biological control. On the basis of X-ray crystal structures of the periplasmic binding protein AccA, coded for by the nopaline Ti C58 plasmid, and affinity studies,
concluded that the importation of agrocin 84 and agrocinopine A both require a pyranose-2-phosphate moiety. We also are in agreement with the necessity for a reducing sugar 2-phosphate for Ti plasmid-coded entry of the agrocinopines and agrocin 84 into the target bacterium. However, because of the loss of biological activity after reduction (
) we are not convinced that the data provided by these authors has proven beyond doubt that the most important motif is the pyranoside species and not an alternative component of the rapidly equilibrating anomeric mixture, especially the acyclic linear aldehyde and/or hydrate.

The essential basis for the control of crown gall pathogens by
R. rhizogenes
strains K84 and K1026 (
) is due to the entry of agrocin 84 via the same transport mechanism as agrocinopines A and C which act as nutrients for pathogen growth.

sec.title: 4.1. Microorganisms
sec.p:
Agrobacterium radiobacter
(formerly
A. tumefaciens
) strain K478, a strain which produces agrocinopine C in its tumours, is also the agrocin 84 overlay strain for detection of agrocinopine C. Strain K478 contains the pTi Bo542 plasmid from the agropine tumour-inducing strain Bo542 and is synonymous with strain A281 (Sciaky et al., 1978), which does not catabolise either octopine or nopaline. Strain K84 the producer strain for agrocin 84 is deposited with NCPPB in the UK . The agrocinopine C producer strain
A. radiobacter
A281 (Syn K478) was generously provided by Dr Mary-Dell Chilton (University of Washington , Seattle, Washington , USA ).

sec.title: 4.2. Isolation of agrocinopine C
4.3. Electrophoresis
4.4. Infrared spectrum
sec.p: The mid-infrared spectrum was obtained using Spectrum One Fourier Transform Infra-Red (FTIR) spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, Massachusetts , USA ) using a diffuse reflectance attachment (Pike Technologies, Madison, Wisconsin , USA . Approximately 10 mg of agrocinopine C was mixed with about 90 mg potassium chloride and loaded into the measurement cell.

sec.title: 4.5. Mass spectrometry
sec.p: Mass spectra were obtained using a high resolution electrospray mass spectrometer (MicroTOF-Q, Bruker Daltonics Corporation, USA ) operated in negative ion mode for analysis. Capillary voltage was set at 3500 V with an end plate offset potential of 500 V. Data were collected from 50 to 1500 m /z with an acquisition rate of 1 s. Dry gas was set to 6 L min 1 at 200 ◦ C with a nebulization gas pressure of 2.0 bar. Samples were introduced by direct infusion.

sec.title: 4.6. NMR spectroscopy
sec.p:
Original 13 C NMR spectra were recorded ( 17.5 mg in 0.5 mL D 2 O) on a JEOL FX-90Q spectrometer. Subsequent 1 H, 31 P and two-dimensional ( 2 mg in 0.6 mL 20% D 2 O) NMR data were obtained using a Varian Inova-600 spectrometer. For comparison, data was obtained for glucose-6-phosphate (Sigma Aldrich), glucose-1-phosphate (Sigma Aldrich) and arabinose-2-phosphate (synthesised by Ryder, 1984 according to the method of
) all at a similar concentration of 2 mg in 0.6 mL 20% D 2 O. The 31 P NMR was measured relative to H 3 PO 4 .
Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: The authors thank Prof Allen Kerr for helpful discussions. A.E.S was the recipient of the R.K. Morton and J.R. Barker scholarships. M.E.T. has funded the completion of this work via the University of Adelaide Alumni Society. NMR data was obtained originally for A.E.S. on a Jeol FX90Q instrument by G.P.J. More recent data was obtained by Phil Clements on a Varian 600 MHz instrument at the University of Adelaide, North Terrace Campus. High resolution MS data was obtained by Jeremy Hack on a Bruker-Daltronics micrOTOF-Q instrument at Metabolomics Australia located within the Australian Wine Research Institute, Urrbrae, South Australia .

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.113013.
